title: Perpetuating behaviour with efficiency
content: Future visions that inform fictions like Star Trek are based on the idea that humans can exceed all limiting boundaries, “Beam me up, Scotty”. In reality, physical laws cannot be dismissed, all human actions are based on the availability of scarce resources. Such scarcity of precious resources leads to the need to economize and rationalise them. As long as humans are highly dependent on precious resources like oil, efficiency will remain a governing principle for human life on Earth. (Morton, 2020) More efficient equals better, therefore efficiency may be called the pleasure of our time. It is the key by which we evaluate our interactions with the material world. That is why increasing efficiency is a cornerstone of most policies and agreements that address change today. (De Decker, 2018a) Approaches based on efficiency operate on a language of numbers and data that indicate trends for certain pieces of pie-charts, camouflaging the actual perpetuation of the status quo. They thereby evoke a sentiment of progress and improvement, yet ultimately fail to convey real meaning. Efficiency-talk always tries to compare, classify or relate numbers, therefore there is a crucial need for context for it to make sense. (De Decker, 2018a) Take the reporting around the CoVid-19 pandemic as an example, as demonstrated, statistics often do little more than reinforcing fear and uncertainty.
